Memorandum by ,the Home Secretary. ^Q A Bill has been introduced by Lord Henry Cavendish Bentinck supported by members of all parties to give local education authorities power to regulate by byolaw the employment of young per- sons between the age3 of 14 and 18. At present, education authorities can regulate the employment of children up to the age of 14 and the employment of street traders up to the age of 16. The employment of young persons in mines and factories is regulated by the nines and Factories Acts, but there is no power to regulate other employment, such as employment of errand boys in connection with shops, employment of van boys, etc., etc. There is much to be said for regulating the employment of young persons over 14, but it is questionable whether it would be possible to take the question up in the present Session and it is also doubt- ful whether it would be wise to propose further regulations, at a time when many young persons find it very difficult to obtain employment of any kind. The present Bill would in any case require much amend- raent and any proposal on the subject would certainly arouse some oppositi on. The Bill is at present being blocked by my direction. If tho Government block were taken off, there is a chance that the Bill might obtain Second Reading without opposition at 11 o'clock some night, As there would seem to be no prospect of dealing properly with this question in tile present Session, I am inclined to retain the block and so avoid having to spend considerable time on the discussion ofC this Bill in Committee, but as the general principles of the Bill commend themselves to many Members in all parties, I should be glad to have the opinion of the Home Affairs Committee on the matter.5th July, 1923.*'f. Co B . 91127. Education (Employment of Young Persons) Bill. MEMORANDUM. The Employment of Children Act, 1903, whichhas now been included in Part VIII. of the education act, 1921, empowered local authorities to make byelawsregulating the employment of children up to 14 yearsof age. Except for those engaged in street tradingor employed in factories and other regulated industries,there is no legislative protection above that age. In order to effect the further supervision and regulation of employment, this Bill extends the presentbyelaw-making power of local education authorities from 14 to 18 years of age. The power is, of course, optional, especially asto what employments and up to what ages the lawis to be extended; and the use of this power is strictly safeguarded by' provisions of Section 105 ofthe Act, as to confirmation of byelaws by the Secretaryof State, public notices, local enquiries, &c.
